Issues.Title: Update Roadmap
Issues.Body:
### Description

The [Roadmap](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/main/roadmap.md) is very much out of date, and haven't seen an update since May 2023. The first table alone still lists things that were completed in .NET 8 Preview 1, and everything on that list is marked as completed.

The .NET 9 Preview 1 blogpost just went live and links to this roadmap and it reflects really poorly on WPF that this roadmap isn't updated along with those announcements.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Update Roadmap" (#8808)

Issues.Title: .NET 8 WPF App - UI Automation Broken - Same App .NET 6 - UI Automation works
Issues.Body:
_This issue has been moved from [a ticket on Developer Community](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/t/NET-8-WPF-App---UI-Automation-Broken---/10576444)._

---
[severity:I'm unable to use this version]
We have a WPF application that tested daily via UI Automation tests. We can currently successfully test and record results when we compile our application as a .NET 6 application. However, when we compile the same application as a .NET 8 application the tests fail to detect some UI elements, which causes our tests to fail.

The UI tree in tools such as (UI Spy, Inspect, Accessibility Insights, etc.) we have discovered that some elements are not displayed in the tool's UI tree. For instance, when using the Inspect.exe tool, and we navigate through a wizard, page by page, only the first wizard page's child controls are displayed in Inspect's UI tree. This behavior is exhibited whether using Raw View, Control View, or Content View.

All tools that we have tried exhibit the same problem.

Issues.Title: Windows 11 theme uses non-standard hand cursors
Issues.Body:
### Description

Current Windows [design guidelines](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/apps/design/input/mouse-interactions#cursors) state to use the arrow cursor ![arrow cursor](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/18747724/5ad1455b-eb27-40c1-b936-0ad3ef96c9b3) and not the hand cursor ![hand cursor](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/18747724/90510297-e194-49b1-8004-975fa88fdeda) for interactive elements.

The following controls styles in the new WPF Windows 11 theme use a hand cursor instead of an arrow cursor:

- `DefaultCheckBoxStyle`
- `DefaultComboBoxItemStyle`
- `DataGridCheckBoxElementDefaultStyle`
- `DefaultRadioButtonStyle`
- `ToolBarButtonBaseStyle`
- `ToolBarOverflowButtonStyle`

The analogous styles in WinUI 3 do not use hand cursors.

### Reproduction Steps

Use the `feature/win11theming/staging-mirror` branch with the new Win11 resources and add combo boxes, checkboxes, radio buttons, etc. Hover over them and observe hand cursors.

### Expected behavior

The cursor should be an arrow ![arrow cursor](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/18747724/5ad1455b-eb27-40c1-b936-0ad3ef96c9b3) when hovering over checkboxes, combo box items, toolbar buttons, etc.

### Actual behavior

The cursor is a hand ![hand cursor](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/assets/18747724/90510297-e194-49b1-8004-975fa88fdeda) over when hovering over these controls.

### Regression?

Previous themes used the recommended cursors.

### Impact

Unexpected change for users of previous style and inconsistency with WinUI, Windows 11, etc.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Windows 11 theme uses non-standard hand cursors" (#8799)

Issues.Title: Fix the automation for merged/closed PRs
Issues.Body:
This is follow-up to #8767. Automation related to closed/merged PRs was not working because of an issue in the migration where there wasn't a condition for checking if a PR was merged. The 'merged' action was carried over as 'Null' in the previous PR.

Issues.Title: ReadLocalValue Within DataTemplate Always Returns UnsetValue
Issues.Body:
### Description

DependencyObject.ReadLocalValue always returns DependencyProperty.UnsetValue if the element is coming from a DataTemplate, irrespective if the value is actually set.

### Reproduction Steps

XAML: Define a DataTemplate for a type. Render the content using any kind of ContentPresenter.
C#: Get the visual content and compare the value returned from ReadLocalValue to the value returned from GetValue.

(MRE here: https://github.com/KatoFett/LocalValueDebugRepo)

### Expected behavior

ReadLocalValue should return the value set in the XAML.

### Actual behavior

ReadLocalValue returns DependencyProperty.UnsetValue.

### Regression?

No.

### Known Workarounds

None.

### Impact

Because we are unable to reliably check whether a property is set locally, it is impossible to conditionally apply bindings or values to properties.

### Configuration

.NET 7 (unable to test 8 yet)

### Other information

_No response_

Issues.Title: Treat CSystemMemoryBitmap stride as unsigned
Issues.Body:
Fixes #5125

## Description

When acquiring lock for a bitmap rectangle, the stride of the bitmap is casted to signed integer. With sufficient large bitmaps, this will result in integer overflow, miscalculation of pixel data offsets and subsequently access violation exception when trying to access the bogus pointer.

This PR removes the cast from UINT to integer, so that the the data offset to the rectangle's top does not overflow to negative numbers.

## Customer Impact

Customers not taking this fix will continue experiencing access violation exceptions when manipulating bitmaps where height*stride > int.Max. 

## Regression

No.

## Testing

Compiled x64 wpfgfx_cor3.dll using MSVC 14.39.33519 and WinSDK 10.0.22621.0, replaced the existing one in .NET 8 and verified the issue in #5125 reproduces before the fix and works after fix on .NET 8.

## Risk

Low. The caller already has the bitmap memory allocated and the rectangle bounds are checked, so the maximum value cannot overflow the available pointer space. Furthermore, similar calculation with UINT stride is already performed elsewhere:

https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/623680775b59a17d730d1c3bfb0f2c558f7a9550/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/WpfGfx/core/sw/swlib/swsurfrt.cpp#L1734-L1736

Issues.Title: Implicit button style size affects Calendar control
Issues.Body:
### Description

If at some level e an implicit button style is declared, and this style sets a minimum size for the button, this affects calendar control within that level (or lower level).

This is hard to diagnose as other items from the button style are not displayed in the calendar control (backgrounds, fonts, borders,...)
It is also odd that setting a Width to about 100px has no effect but setting a MinWidth for 100px increases the default calendar width by a factor 1.75

The issue seems to be related to the left right buttons for month selection

### Reproduction Steps

```
<Grid>
    <Grid.RowDefinitions>
        <RowDefinition Height="*"/>
        <RowDefinition Height="*"/>
    </Grid.RowDefinitions>
    <Grid Grid.Row="0">
        <!-- Normal sized calendar -->
        <Calendar></Calendar>
    </Grid>
    <Grid Grid.Row="1">
        <Grid.Resources>
            <Style TargetType="Button">
                <Setter Property="MinWidth" Value="100"/>
            </Style>
        </Grid.Resources>
        <!-- Affected calendar -->
        <Calendar></Calendar>
    </Grid>
</Grid>
``` 

### Expected behavior

Either ignore button style completely or incorporate it completely

### Actual behavior

Button style partly used.

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

Don't use implicit button style sizing at that level

### Impact

The impact is largely about finding the cause, once you have it workaround is relatively easy. But to me the cause was pretty unclear.

### Configuration

.net 8.0

### Other information
